0.text: So there's an early election on. Agh!

2.text:
Today I'm going to Birmingham to talk to Jess
Phillips.

5.text:
Now, Jess Phillips, you know she has her strong
admirers,

9.text:
she has her detractors but if we don't keep
seats like that

13.text: we're in a bit of a mess.

14.text: So I want to find out, how is it in Birmingham?

18.text: What's the mood on the ground?

19.text: And what's the future for Labour?

21.text:
Hiya! Hey everyone, how are you doing? You
alright?

35.text: That side of the road you're with John.

37.text: John, you're on that side of the road.

44.text:
In some of the polling at the moment, obviously
the Tories have a whopping big lead.

49.text: But Labour's vote at the moment is kind of...

51.text: They're on about what they were on last time.

55.text:
Yes, but Tory voters are much more likely
to be, you know,

60.text: they'll vote around. They'll vote around.

64.text: Yeah, they like to be wooed.

67.text:
Whereas people who vote Labour are, I think,
a lot more tribal

73.text:
and I think people will vote for what they
know.

76.text:
Also, because people don't really want this
election, so ...

78.text:
Is that coming up? Are people on the doorstep
going ...?

80.text:
Oh god! All the time! That woman from Bristol
in that famous film.

84.text:
Yeah, they're like: 'Get on with your job,
love. You've only just started.'

89.text:
I'm like: 'Believe you me, I did not want
this election.

93.text:
A lot of people think all people want to talk
about

96.text: That's the narrative of the press at the moment.

97.text: Not at all. Not at all.

98.text:
So people aren't going: 'I'm a leaver. I'm
a remainer.

102.text: Not at all. Not at all.

105.text:
People talk to me genuinely more about Gogglebox
than they do about Brexit.

109.text: Ha ha! It's a big issue.

112.text:
This is Habib, who is a Yardley campaigning
legend.

117.text:
I used to have a shoe shop up on the road
so they used to all come in.

121.text: That's a great way of getting to know people.

126.text:
If someone forgets their phone number he goes:
'It's alright.'

127.text:
And he goes through his phone and gets the
phone number.

132.text:
If I was going to ask you for the top three
issues in this constituency,

136.text: what do you reckon they are?

139.text:
The single biggest issue is always pavement
politics.

142.text: It is stuff about the grass verges, the bins.

145.text:
Do people complain about, I've noticed a lot
of this on the doorstep,

147.text:
other people's gardens? They get really angry
about it.

151.text: Oh my god, yeah! Other people's gardens, yeah.

153.text: Big trees in other people's gardens.

156.text: So I'd put all of that into one category.

162.text: And then I would say housing.

166.text: The fact that people can't afford to buy houses

168.text:
and people are inappropriately housed in my
constituency is really bad.

174.text: Have you had any Lib Dems?

176.text:
No, not yet. I haven't really had anyone yet
to be honest.

179.text: Well, today yeah but not right now.

183.text:
No, we're talking about now. Have you got
anyone voting for anyone yet?

187.text: Maybe you need to ask the other team.

191.text:
Did you watch Theresa May on the One Show
the other day?

193.text:
I didn't. I've only seen the really cringey
shoe thing.

196.text:
In a lift where she said a woman said to her
she got involved

199.text: in politics because of Theresa May's shoes?

201.text: I mean, give me actual strength.

204.text:
It is true that polling and anecdotal stuff
backs it up,

208.text: a lot of people seem to quite like her,

211.text:
which for people like me and you is a bit
odd, maybe.

214.text:
Why? Come on, what do you think it is? Why
is she (so popular)?

217.text:
I think that the Tories have essentially created
a sense

221.text: of complete instability in the country,

223.text:
which is ironic considering what their lovely
catchphrases are.

228.text: She is sort of like a phoenix from the ashes

230.text: which she lit the paper on.

237.text: and they promote that sense of chaos

239.text:
but claim they're the only thing that can
stabilise

241.text: the chaos that they themselves have caused.

243.text: It is clever. It's clever if you can do it.

246.text:
If you have the money and the PR to do it
and if you have

248.text:
essentially a lightning rod, which they feel
they have in Jeremy Corbyn,

253.text:
they can charge themselves up like the power
of Greyskull.

260.text: But people just want a simpler life.

263.text:
This is my favourite named street in Yardley:
Fast Pits Road.

269.text: I don't know why I'm laughing so loud.

277.text: So you've been an MP now for two years.

278.text:
It's been a very quiet, uneventful period
in British history.

281.text: What are you most proud of?

282.text:
I am most proud of raising the profile of
domestic violence victims,

287.text: and for actually changing the law so that no perpetrator

293.text: of domestic violence will ever be allowed

295.text: to question their victim in a family court.

298.text:
I am also proud, the most proud, I think actually
was to stand

305.text: with the families of the Birmingham pub bombings

308.text: and get them the legal aid that they deserved

310.text:
because it was like a proper David and Goliath
story.

313.text:
What's been the worst thing about being an
MP?

315.text: Oh god! I don't like being away from my family

318.text: and, whilst I'm no fan of the snap election,

320.text:
the pleasure of waking up in my own bed every
day

326.text:
It's very, very difficult for people with
young families, I think,

329.text: to be members of parliament. So, that is difficult.

332.text:
And, you know, we suffered a terrible, terrible
loss when Jo [Cox] was killed

336.text:
and feeling like you're in a class of people
who is now hunted –

342.text:
and for journalists it's the same actually,
I think,

346.text: it's a similar thing – isn't the best.

351.text:
All I'm trying to do, genuinely and I know
it sounds trite and rubbish,

355.text: is trying to like make things better for people

358.text: and then I became a target because of that.

360.text:
I mean, there's some people, really, like
much worse than me.

365.text:
Ha ha! Some really, genuinely, malevolent
people out there.

369.text:
Yeah, why me? I mean, I'm just like trying
to help Betty with her tree

373.text:
and the flats at the back of her house and
like, you know,

376.text:
sort out this youth centre just over the road,
which we managed to save

380.text:
and people want to kill me because of it.
Weird.

388.text: If Labour is a family, which I think it is,

390.text:
is Labour going to stay together after whatever
happens?

395.text:
Yeah, I mean, I think so because I think that
that tribal tendency

398.text: is really hard to shake, isn't it?

400.text: I remember once that I tried not to vote Labour

402.text:
and my hand was like a Ouija Board. I couldn't
not do it.

407.text: I think it will come back together

408.text:
but like when you have a falling out with
your family,

412.text:
which I do all the time, everybody has to
give a little bit.

416.text:
I think that the trouble is that there's certain
factions

422.text: that will not give an inch from both sides.

426.text:
That has got to stop because we're going to
be ...

429.text:
I hope that we're going to get like, you know
that bit

431.text:
in between Christmas and New Year that everybody
really likes

433.text:
because you don't have to go and do anything,
there's no no obligations.

436.text:
I hope that after the election, when everyone's
so tired

439.text:
and so stuffed full of turkey, that we're
going to sit around together

442.text:
and watch a crap film that we've all seen
before and feel a bit better.

446.text: Then there's the dirty washing up.

448.text: Someone's going to have to clean that up.

449.text: Yeah, that'll be the Labour women.

452.text:
The Labour women, they always clean up the
mess.

454.text: So I'm an opinion writer. I'm an activist.

456.text: I don't pretend to be neutral or objective.

458.text:
I want Labour to do well in this election
and what I found from today

463.text: is there is some ground for some optimism.

465.text:
This is so hard. All the odds are stacked
against Labour,

468.text: there's no point in pretending otherwise.

470.text:
But, it does show, if you get people out knocking
on doors and campaigning

473.text: it's the only way to turn things around.

475.text: So, I thought that was interesting and I want to see what you think.

481.text: A lot of you won't agree with me. Good.

482.text: I want to hear from you.

484.text: Subscribe. I'll see you next time.
